instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00687: What is 820-00687? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.PP5V_G3H: What is PP5V_G3H? PP5V_G3H is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state.
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP5VS4_EN: What is PP5VS4_EN? P5VS4_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP5V_S4 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that doesn't  power on. On the ampmeter it puls 20.5V, but 0A. Already tried a new flex cable, but no success.

I'm using one boardview and schematics of a 244 (not sure if this is OK, but don't have a 687)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.68V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 8.68V
<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> = 20.54V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H</SIGNAL> = 5.1V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5.1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V

On <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>, mesuaring on <RESISTOR>R7801</RESISTOR> I only get 1.6V; On L4802, I only get 1.6V, and on pin 12 of <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> I get 0V.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
I'n wondering how do you get <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> without <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, nor even <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.
Re-check your measurments...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Sorry, you're right.
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.1V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 5.1V

The other mesuarements are correct.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
To enter S4 state, board must pass through SUS first.
Still unclear ho do you get S4 voltage, but no <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> missing for sure?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Hi,

Unless my schematics is wrong (I'm using a 244 board schematics), I think that I'm reading it corectly.

I'm measuring  <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>  on <CAPACITOR>C6100</CAPACITOR>, and <CAPACITOR>C6101</CAPACITOR>, and I get 0V on both.

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R1554</RESISTOR> has 0V also.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> has 5.1V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>  on L4802 has 1.7V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
From schematic looks this board has different behavior for SUS state.

If you get <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL>, then <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL> must be present too; same enable signal is used for both rails.
Check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>.
If good, then change <CHIP>U8200</CHIP>.
Be sure to get 3V at its ON pin.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
diode on  <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>  seams to be ok (0.491).

Do you know if I can use a component from a 244 boarde, and witch one? I don't have any other 687, an I'm not identifying one on the 244 board...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Hi,
Diode reading on <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is ok (0.491).
I've replaced <CHIP>U8200</CHIP> but no sucess. However, now on  <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL> I have 2.83V.

Voltages on <CHIP>U8200</CHIP>: I have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> (3.3V), but on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> (pin 6) I have 0.055V. Can it be <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> or a bad <CHIP>U8200</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
The same <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is present at pin 4 of <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>.
Check for continuity.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
I don't have continuity from <CHIP>U8200</CHIP> to <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>, but i have from <CHIP>U8200</CHIP> to <RESISTOR>R8305</RESISTOR> (pin 1), and I have from <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> to <RESISTOR>R8305</RESISTOR> (Pin 2).

On <RESISTOR>R8305</RESISTOR> I read 9.96 kohm, but my schematic doesn't have <RESISTOR>R8305</RESISTOR> (and I don't have other board to compare), and so I'm not sure if the value is the correct one. Do you think that it can be it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Are you using 00244 schematic?
I can't find <RESISTOR>R8305</RESISTOR> there.

You must check continuity for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Hi, yes, I'm using 00244 schematic and boardview.

I've checked continuity of <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> from <CHIP>U8200</CHIP> to <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>, but it doesn't have continuity.

The schematic doesn't have it, but the boardview shows it (<RESISTOR>R8305</RESISTOR>).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message: What is the voltage on both pins of R/<DIODE>D8305</DIODE>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
<DIODE>D8305</DIODE> is a no stuf. However, on pads I have:
1 = 0V
2 = 0.034V

<RESISTOR>R8305</RESISTOR>:
1 = 0.034V
2 =  0.053V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
<DIODE>D8305</DIODE> is a no stuf. However, on pads I have:
1 = 0V
2 = 0.034V

<RESISTOR>R8305</RESISTOR>:
1 = 0.034V
2 =  0.053V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Then you don't have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>.
How then do you get <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL>?

Possible there are more differences between board and schematic.
If <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is really present at <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>, then wire it to <CHIP>U8200</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
After replacing (twice) <CHIP>U8200</CHIP>, because I broked it, now I don't have <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> (0V), neither <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> (0V), and only have 0.650V on <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>.

I have  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> (3.3V), and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> (5.0V)

<SIGNAL>PP5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> pin 4 of <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> has 0.054V

<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>   = 0.003V

Possiblly, the heat damage something else?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Did you get <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> present at <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> for sure before?
I suppose PCH problem; possibly affected by the heat now.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
I never had <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>. I had 5.1V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>, but I didn't measured it on <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>; I've used <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> to measured <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> , and I'm sure that there I had 5.1V.

Shall I try to replace <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Why, if is not enabled?

Really strange to got <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> before; <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> requires high level at pin 4 for that.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
I understood your point, but I'm not sure if I had it there before, because I didn't cheked. I suppose I had it.

Can't it be <CHIP>U5000</CHIP>? <RESISTOR>R1553</RESISTOR> should be 100k ohm (i think) but I'm reading a lot of oscilating values on it. Do you think that this can be related?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
PCH is the one in charge to release <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals.
Of course, it requires some other previous signals; like RTC and S5 power.
